clusters.title: Handbags, $10k gold bar seized after 'fortune teller' arrested for fraud
clusters.neutral_headline: Fortune Teller Arrested for Alleged $70 Million Fraud

items.title: Handbags, $10k gold bar seized after 'fortune teller' arrested for fraud
items.standfirst: The 53-year-old told clients a "billionaire" was in their future, allegedly persuading them to take out financial loans before keeping a share for herself.
items.content: The 53-year-old told clients a "billionaire" was in their future, allegedly persuading them to take out financial loans before keeping a share for herself.

items.title: Fortune teller accused of carrying out $70 million fraud
items.standfirst: S he allegedly persuaded victims to take out loans based on her prediction of a billionaire figure in their future.
items.content: A self-proclaimed fortune teller has been charged today over an alleged $70 million fraud in Sydney.The 53-year-old woman, who claimed to be a feng shui master and fortune teller, and a 25-year-old woman were arrested yesterday at a Dover Heights property in the city's eastern suburbs.The older woman is accused of exploiting vulnerable clients in Sydney's Vietnamese community.READ MORE: Epstein claimed Trump knew about his conduct, newly released emails say She allegedly persuaded victims to take out financial loans – while taking a share herself – based on her prediction that there was a "billionaire" in their future.The fraud, allegedly orchestrated with the help from the younger woman, is estimated to total nearly $70 million. During the pair's arrest, police also seized financial documents, mobile phones, other electronics, luxury handbags, a 40-gram gold bar worth $10,000 and $6600 in casino chips.The NSW Crime Commission froze an additional $15 million worth of assets.The older woman has been charged with 39 offences, including dishonestly obtaining financial advantage by deception and dealing with the proceeds of crime.She was refused bail and is due to appear in court today.The younger woman was charged with offences including obtaining financial advantage by deception and dealing with the proceeds of crime.She was granted conditional bail and is scheduled to appear in court tomorrow.Police allege the women were part of a fraud and money laundering syndicate operating across Sydney.Commander of the NSW Police financial crimes squad, Detective Superintendent Gordon Arbinja said they came to the attention of Strike Force Myddleton detectives investigating a criminal syndicate targeting vehicle financing companies."What began as an investigation into fraudulent car financing has expanded into uncovering one of the most sophisticated financial crime syndicates I have seen in my career at the helm of the Financial Crimes Squad," he said.To date, the NSW Crime Commission has frozen $75 million linked to the crime syndicate. Sign up here to receive our daily newsletters and breaking news alerts, sent straight to your inbox.

ai_summary: A fortune teller was arrested for allegedly carrying out a $70 million fraud.
She allegedly persuaded victims to take out loans based on predictions.
The fortune teller told clients a "billionaire" was in their future.
She allegedly kept a share of the loans for herself.
Handbags and a $10,000 gold bar were seized in the arrest.
